com.dataartisans.flinktraining.exercises.datastream_java.process

Class EventTimeJoinFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.AbstractRichFunction
      • org.apache.flink.streaming.api.functions.co.RichCoProcessFunction<Trade,Customer,EnrichedTrade>
        • com.dataartisans.flinktraining.exercises.datastream_scala.lowlatencyjoin.EventTimeJoinHelper
          • com.dataartisans.flinktraining.exercises.datastream_java.process.EventTimeJoinFunction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.Function, org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.RichFunction, org.apache.flink.streaming.api.functions.co.CoProcessFunction<Trade,Customer,EnrichedTrade>

    public class EventTimeJoinFunction
extends com.dataartisans.flinktraining.exercises.datastream_scala.lowlatencyjoin.EventTimeJoinHelper
    This is a homegrown join function using the new Flink 1.2 ProcessFunction. Basically, what we do is the following: 1) When we receive a trade we join it against the customer data right away, however to keep this 100% deterministic we join against the latest customer data that has a timestamp LESS THAN the trade timestamp -- not simply the latest available data. In other words we are joining against the customer data that we knew at the time of the trade. 2) We also set a trigger to evaluate the trade again once the watermark has passed the trade time. Basically, what we're doing here is using event time to ensure that we have "complete" data and then joining again at that time. This will give us a deterministic result even in the face of undordered data, etc This approach has the benefit that you don't introduce any latency into the trade stream because you always join right away. You then emit a BETTER result if you receive better information. We use event time in order to know how long we must wait for this potential better information. We also use event time to know when it's safe to expire state.
    See Also:
